title: Who Am I?
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "And you have been made complete in Him, who is the head of all rule and authority."

content.heading: Introduction: The Crisis of Identity
paragraphs: Who am I?
This is one of the deepest questions every human being wrestles with. In today's world, people try to define themselves in countless ways...
...But Colossians 2:10 declares a powerful truth: 'You have been made complete in Him.'

content.heading: Point 1: The World Offers a False Identity
paragraphs: The world constantly tells us, 'Define yourself.'
It urges people to create their own identity based on feelings, performance, or culture. But this leads to confusion and instability...
...No earthly identity can satisfy the soul because we were not created to define ourselves—we were created to be defined by God.

content.heading: Point 2: Our Identity in Christ—Complete, Not Lacking
paragraphs: Colossians 2:10 says, 'You have been made complete in Him.'
What does it mean to be 'complete in Christ'?
1. We Lack Nothing for Salvation...
2. We Lack Nothing for Acceptance...
3. We Lack Nothing for Purpose...
4. We Lack Nothing for Security...
...The world says, 'Find yourself.' But God says, 'You are already complete in Christ.'

content.heading: Point 3: How the Gospel Makes This Possible
paragraphs: How do we become complete in Christ? Through the Gospel:
1. Christ Restores Our True Identity...
2. Christ Gives Us a New Name...
3. Christ Fulfills Our Deepest Longings...
4. Christ Replaces Our Self-Definition...
...Because of Christ, we no longer need to search for significance in anything else.

content.heading: Point 4: Living from Our Identity in Christ
paragraphs: If we are already complete in Christ, how should we live?
1. Stop Striving for Worth in Temporary Things...
2. Let Go of False Labels...
3. Find Satisfaction in Christ, Not Ministry...
4. Live with Boldness and Peace...
...We don't have to prove ourselves—we are already fully loved, fully accepted, and fully complete in Jesus.

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Finding Your Identity?
paragraphs: Are you trying to define yourself by success, ministry, or approval from others?
Are you looking to Christ alone, or are you searching for something more?
Do you truly believe you are complete in Him?
...True peace and purpose come when we stop looking to the world for identity and rest in who we are in Christ.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, I confess that I have often sought my identity in things that cannot satisfy. But Your Word says I am complete in Christ. Help me to rest in this truth and live from the identity You have given me. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Take time today to write down all the ways you have defined yourself apart from Christ. Then, replace each one with what God says about you in Scripture (e.g., "I am loved," "I am forgiven," "I am complete in Him").

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: The world says, 'You must create your identity.'
The Gospel says, 'Your identity is already complete in Christ.'
...Rest in Him—you lack nothing.

title: Seeking God Beyond Convenience
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "You will seek me and find me when you seek me with all your heart."

content.heading: Introduction: A Faith of Convenience?
paragraphs: In a world filled with distractions, it is easy to make our time with God a matter of convenience rather than commitment.
We pray when we have time, but never make time.
We read Scripture when it fits into our schedule, but never schedule it.
We worship when we feel like it, but neglect it when life gets busy.
A relationship with God that is based on convenience will always be shallow, inconsistent, and powerless. True devotion is about seeking God with all our hearts, not just when it is easy.

content.heading: 1. Convenience Devotion vs. Costly Devotion
paragraphs: Many approach devotion with a mindset of minimal effort—fitting it into life's leftover moments. But Jesus calls us to a costly devotion.
### Convenience Devotion – Gives God time only when it is easy
* Prays only in emergencies.
* Reads the Bible without applying it.
* Attends church if nothing else is scheduled.
Costly Devotion – Seeks God above all else
* Prays persistently (Luke 18:1).
* Treasures God's Word daily (Psalm 1:2).
* Makes worship a priority (Hebrews 10:25).
Jesus said, "If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me" (Luke 9:23). True devotion requires sacrifice and commitment.

content.heading: 2. The Danger of a Shallow Relationship
paragraphs: If our pursuit of God is occasional, our faith will be weak.
* Shallow devotion leads to weak faith (Matthew 13:20-21).
* Inconsistent devotion leads to spiritual dryness (John 15:4-5).
* Neglecting devotion leads to distance from God (James 4:8).
Convenience-based devotion is like a plant with shallow roots—it cannot withstand trials. But when we prioritize time with God, our faith grows deep and strong.

content.heading: 3. Seeking God Wholeheartedly
paragraphs: God does not promise to reveal Himself to those who seek Him casually but to those who seek Him wholeheartedly.
1. Set a Fixed Time – Make devotion a priority, not an afterthought (Daniel 6:10).
2. Remove Distractions – Find a quiet place and give God your full attention (Matthew 6:6).
3. Engage Your Heart – Read, pray, and worship with intentionality, not just routine (Psalm 119:11).
God desires deep relationship, not just routine practice.

content.heading: Application: How Are You Seeking God?
paragraphs: Are you seeking God only when it is convenient, or do you pursue Him with all your heart?
Is your devotional life consistent and intentional, or occasional and shallow?
What steps can you take to make God your first priority every day?

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, forgive me for seeking You only when it is easy. Teach me to desire You above all else. Help me to seek You with my whole heart and to make time with You a priority, not an option. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Evaluate your daily routine. Identify one thing you can remove or adjust to prioritize time with God consistently.

content.heading: Final Thought
paragraphs: A faith of convenience will always be weak. A faith of commitment will always be strong.
Seek God with all your heart—He is worth it.

title: Thirsting for More: Broken Cisterns vs. Living Water
author: Daram Ajay
scriptureContent: "For my people have committed two evils: they have forsaken me, the fountain of living waters, and hewed out cisterns for themselves, broken cisterns that can hold no water."

content.heading: Introduction: The Universal Thirst
paragraphs: Have you ever felt like no matter what you achieve, buy, or pursue, there's still an emptiness inside? The world offers many things that seem to promise satisfaction—success, relationships, pleasure, entertainment—but in the end, they leave us thirsting for more.

The prophet Jeremiah delivered this message during King Josiah's reign (627–609 BCE), a time of religious reform (2 Kings 22–23). God, through Jeremiah, brought a covenant lawsuit against Judah, accusing them of two sins:

1. They abandoned Yahweh, the "fountain of living waters." Flowing water in Scripture represents divine sustenance, holiness, and life. But Judah severed their covenant bond, choosing spiritual dryness over God's unending provision.

2. They turned to "broken cisterns that can hold no water." Instead of trusting in God, they relied on idolatry, foreign alliances (Egypt and Assyria), and self-reliance. These pursuits were as leaky as cracked reservoirs—incapable of security or fulfillment.

Though Josiah's reforms sought to eradicate idolatry, Jeremiah's message suggests their repentance was superficial—Judah's heart was still divided. Their paradox was tragic: they exchanged infinite grace for finite, crumbling substitutes.
This message remains painfully relevant today. We, too, turn to modern "broken cisterns," thinking they will satisfy, only to find ourselves spiritually drained.

content.heading: Point 1: Broken Cisterns – The Illusion of Satisfaction
paragraphs: Modern society offers many "cisterns" that seem to promise fulfillment, but they cannot hold water:

• Pornography & Sexual Immorality – Many turn to sexual pleasure to fill emotional or relational emptiness. While it offers momentary excitement, it often leads to addiction, guilt, and greater dissatisfaction. It cannot replace the intimacy and love that only Christ can provide.

• Social Media & Approval Seeking – The pursuit of likes, comments, and recognition can feel fulfilling at first, but it breeds comparison, anxiety, and an endless thirst for validation. True worth is found in Christ, not in the approval of people.
• Success & Workaholism – Achievements, promotions, and financial gains can seem satisfying, but no amount of success ever feels like "enough." Without Christ, our work remains an empty pursuit.

• Entertainment & Escapism – Movies, video games, social media scrolling—these can numb our pain for a while, but they do not address our deep longing for meaning and joy. Christ offers real peace, not just temporary distraction.
• Substance Abuse & Addictions – Alcohol, drugs, and unhealthy habits promise relief but only deepen the emptiness inside. They enslave rather than satisfy.
• Relationships & Romantic Love – Some seek fulfillment in relationships, believing that human love can complete them. But no person can fill the God-shaped void in our hearts.
These cisterns leak—they promise satisfaction but fail to hold water. They cannot truly quench our spiritual thirst.

content.heading: Point 2: Christ – The Fountain of Living Water
paragraphs: In contrast to these empty pursuits, Christ is a fountain—a never-ending source of true satisfaction. Jesus said in John 4:14:
"Whoever drinks the water I give them will never thirst. Indeed, the water I give them will become in them a spring of water welling up to eternal life."
Why Can Christ Meet Our Deepest Needs?
Unlike broken cisterns, Christ never runs dry because:
1. He is the Source of Life – Just as water is essential for physical life, Jesus is essential for spiritual life. Without Him, we remain spiritually dead in sin (John 7:37-38).
2. He Alone Can Satisfy the Soul – Everything else leaves us longing for more, but Jesus completes us. He offers lasting joy, not just temporary pleasure (Psalm 16:11).
3. He Gives Us True Security – Worldly things can be lost—money, relationships, achievements—but Christ never leaves or forsakes us (Hebrews 13:5).
How Does Christ Satisfy Our Deepest Needs?
1. Through His Presence – When we abide in Him, He fills our hearts with peace that surpasses understanding (Philippians 4:7).
2. Through His Word – The Scriptures nourish us, guide us, and remind us of His promises (Matthew 4:4).
3. Through the Holy Spirit – The Spirit dwells in us, producing love, joy, and peace that worldly pursuits cannot provide (Galatians 5:22-23).
4. Through His Sacrifice – On the cross, Jesus paid the price for our sin, making it possible for us to be reconciled to God. Only through Him can we find eternal satisfaction (John 6:35).
Rather than running after temporary satisfactions, we must learn to drink deeply from Christ—His Word, His presence, and His promises.

content.heading: Application: Where Are You Drinking From?
paragraphs: Ask yourself:
• Am I relying on temporary things to quench my thirst?
• Have I truly found satisfaction in Christ, or am I still searching?
• What broken cisterns in my life need to be abandoned so I can drink deeply from Christ?
If you've been drinking from broken cisterns, it's time to turn to the fountain of living water. Christ alone can satisfy your soul.

content.heading: Prayer
paragraphs: "Lord, I confess that I have sought satisfaction in things that cannot truly fulfill me. Help me to turn away from broken cisterns and drink deeply from You, the fountain of living water. Satisfy my soul with Your presence and love. Amen."

content.heading: Action Step
paragraphs: Spend time in prayer today, asking God to reveal the broken cisterns in your life. Read John 6:35, where Jesus declares,
"I am the bread of life; whoever comes to me shall not hunger, and whoever believes in me shall never thirst."
Surrender your desires to Christ and ask Him to be your true source of satisfaction.
